items.title: China develops heat pump to transform heavy industry

featured_image.name: China's ultra-hot heat pump breakthrough paves way for ...

items.description:
Chinese scientists have developed an ultra-high-temperature heat pump that breaks through a century-old technical barrier, potentially enabling solar energy or industrial waste heat to power some of the world's most energy-intensive manufacturing processes.

The device, created by researchers at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, achieved an output temperature of 270 degrees Celsius using a 145-degree heat source—shattering the long-standing practical limit of around 200 degrees that has constrained industrial heat pump technologies for decades[1][2][3]. The breakthrough was published in multiple journals including Nature Energy, Applied Physics Letters, and Energy in 2025[2][4][5].

items.title: Pentagon refuses to release Venezuela boat strike video

featured_image.name: Public won't see Venezuela second strike video: Hegseth

items.description:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced Tuesday that the Pentagon will not make public the full footage of a controversial September 2 military strike that killed two survivors clinging to wreckage off Venezuela's coast, defying bipartisan calls for transparency[1][2][3].

Speaking alongside Secretary of State Marco Rubio after briefing senators, Hegseth stated that releasing the classified video would violate "long-standing Department of Defense policy."[1][4] The footage, which Hegseth described as "top-secret," will instead be shown only to the House and Senate Armed Services Committees on Wednesday, with Admiral Frank Bradley—who ordered the strike—in attendance[1][2].

items.title: Webb telescope finds exoplanets that defy formation theories

featured_image.name: James Webb Space Telescope discovers a lemon-shaped exoplanet unlike anything seen before: 'What the heck is this?'

items.description: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has identified two exoplanets with atmospheres that defy conventional understanding, challenging long-held theories about how planets form and survive in extreme environments. The discoveries, announced this week, include a lemon-shaped world with an atmosphere dominated by carbon and helium, and a lava planet that retains a thick gaseous envelope despite scorching stellar radiation[1][2][3].

items.title: Global stocks fall as jobs data, Ukraine talks rattle markets

featured_image.name: Stocks retreat ahead of US jobs data, oil drops on Ukraine hopes

items.description: World stocks fell and oil prices hit multi‑month lows on Tuesday, as investors braced for delayed U.S. jobs figures that could reshape interest‑rate expectations and weighed the prospect that a Russia‑Ukraine peace deal might eventually unlock fresh supplies of Russian crude.[1][2][3]

items.title: Scientists link mysterious blue space flashes to black holes

featured_image.name: Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transient (Artist's Concept ...

items.description:
Astronomers have finally identified the source of enigmatic bright blue flashes in space, resolving a decade-long mystery that has puzzled scientists since these rare cosmic phenomena were first detected.

The brief, brilliant bursts known as luminous fast blue optical transients, or LFBOTs, are caused by intermediate-mass black holes completely shredding their massive star companions in a violent process called extreme tidal disruption, according to research from the University of California, Berkeley published this week[1][2]. Analysis of the brightest such event ever recorded—AT2024wpp, discovered in September 2024—revealed energy levels 100 times greater than typical supernovae, ruling out stellar explosions as the cause[1][2].

"The sheer amount of radiated energy from these bursts is so large that you can't power them with the collapse and explosion of a massive star — or any other type of normal stellar explosion," said Natalie LeBaron, a Berkeley graduate student and first author of one of two papers recently accepted by The Astrophysical Journal Letters[1].

items.title: Natural disasters caused $220B in global losses in 2025

featured_image.name: Natural disasters hit global economy for $220bn in 2025: Swiss Re

items.description:
Global economic losses from natural catastrophes fell 33 percent to $220 billion in 2025, down from $327 billion the previous year, according to a report released Tuesday by Swiss Re, though the reinsurance giant cautioned that elevated disaster costs have become the "new baseline" rather than outliers.

Insured losses reached $107 billion, marking the sixth consecutive year that figure exceeded $100 billion, the Zurich-based company said[1][2][3][4][5]. The United States accounted for 83 percent of global insured losses, driven primarily by the costliest wildfire event in history and severe convective storms[2][3][6].

The January wildfires that tore through Los Angeles's Pacific Palisades and other affluent neighborhoods caused $40 billion in insured losses alone, Swiss Re reported[7][2][3][4]. The fires destroyed more than 23,000 acres, leveling homes and businesses and forcing thousands to evacuate[2][3].

items.title: US unemployment hits four-year high at 4.6%

featured_image.name: What to expect from the jobs report today

items.description:
The US unemployment rate climbed to 4.6% in November, the highest level since September 2021, according to delayed government data released Tuesday, as employers added 64,000 jobs amid mounting concerns about the labor market's health[1][2][3][4].

The Bureau of Labor Statistics report, postponed by a 43-day government shutdown, revealed that the economy lost 105,000 jobs in October before rebounding modestly last month[1][5][6]. The November job gains exceeded economists' forecasts of 40,000 to 50,000 positions, though the rising unemployment rate dampened relief over the better-than-expected hiring figures[1][2][4].

Stock market futures turned slightly positive following the release, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq each rising approximately 0.1% after initially wavering[7][8]. The mixed economic signals intensified debate over whether the Federal Reserve will continue cutting interest rates in 2026[1][5].

items.title: Global markets tumble as US jobs data shows rising unemployment

featured_image.name: Wall St futures slip as investors brace for key jobs report

items.description:
Global equity markets tumbled Tuesday as investors braced for the long-awaited US November employment report, while persistent concerns about artificial intelligence valuations weighed on technology stocks across trading sessions.

Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 1.6% to 49,383.29, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng declined 1.5% and China's Shanghai Composite dropped 1.1%[1][2][3]. The selloff in Asian markets reflected mounting caution ahead of critical US economic data that could shape the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory in 2026.

European markets opened mixed but largely lower, with investors rotating into defensive sectors like healthcare and utilities while technology and industrial shares lagged[4][2]. The Euro Stoxx 50 showed modest gains of 0.6% early in trading, though broader sentiment remained fragile[2].

items.title: Interstellar comet to make closest pass by Earth Friday

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS caught on camera in new ... - Space

items.description:
A rare visitor from another star system will make its closest pass by Earth on Friday, December 19, offering astronomers their final opportunity to study a cosmic wanderer that has mystified scientists with an unusual sunward jet pointing in the opposite direction of typical comet tails.

Comet 3I/ATLAS will come no closer than approximately 167 million miles from Earth—nearly twice the distance between Earth and the Sun—posing no threat to the planet, according to the European Space Agency[1][2]. The flyby marks a crucial moment for researchers racing to unlock the secrets of only the third confirmed interstellar object ever detected passing through our solar system[1][3].

items.title: European stocks fall amid Ukraine peace hopes, central bank meetings

featured_image.name: European shares edge lower ahead of crucial US jobs data

items.description:
European markets declined on Tuesday as investors adopted a cautious stance ahead of crucial central bank policy decisions and delayed US employment reports, while defense stocks tumbled on renewed hopes for a Russia-Ukraine peace agreement.

The pan-European STOXX 600 index fell 0.1% to 581.87 as of midday trading, following its largest single-day gain in nearly three weeks on Monday[1][2]. Germany's DAX dropped 0.5%, while France's CAC 40 declined 0.1% and the UK's FTSE 100 fell 0.3%[3][4].

items.title: Japanese researchers create heat-resistant aluminum using iron

featured_image.name: How 3D printing creates stronger vehicle parts by solving ...

items.description:
Researchers at Nagoya University in Japan have developed a new aluminum alloy that maintains strength and flexibility at temperatures up to 300°C, potentially enabling lighter and more efficient engines for cars and aircraft. The breakthrough, published in Nature Communications on December 15, challenges traditional metallurgical practices by using iron—typically considered a contaminant—as a crucial strengthening component[1][2][3][4][5].

Professor Naoki Takata and his team at Nagoya University's Graduate School of Engineering created the alloy series using laser powder bed fusion, a 3D printing technique that rapidly solidifies molten metal. The best-performing variant combines aluminum with iron, manganese, and titanium (Al-Fe-Mn-Ti), achieving tensile strength exceeding 250 MPa at 300°C while maintaining room-temperature ductility of 14-17%[5].

items.title: AI chip shortage to drive up phone prices, cut shipments

featured_image.name: Smartphones With 4GB RAM May Become A Thing Again In 2026

items.description: Global smartphone shipments are expected to fall 2.1% in 2026 as a shortage of memory chips—driven by surging demand from artificial intelligence data centers—pushes costs higher across the industry, according to a report released Tuesday by technology market research firm Counterpoint Research[1][2][3][4][5][6]. The forecast marks a sharp reversal from an estimated 3.3% gain in 2025 and reflects the mounting pressure on manufacturers as AI companies compete with consumer electronics makers for dwindling memory supplies[3][6].

items.title: China sets five-year tariffs on EU pork imports

featured_image.name: China lowers anti-dumping tariffs on European pork exporters

items.description:
China announced Tuesday it will impose anti-dumping tariffs of up to 19.8 percent on European Union pork imports for five years, concluding an 18-month investigation widely seen as retaliation for the bloc's duties on Chinese electric vehicles. The final tariff rates, ranging from 4.9 to 19.8 percent, represent a reduction from preliminary levies of up to 62.4 percent imposed in September[1][2][3][4][5].

The duties take effect Wednesday and will last through December 2030, covering more than $2 billion in annual EU pork exports to China[4][5][6]. China's Ministry of Commerce determined that European exporters were "dumping" pork and pig by-products in the Chinese market at prices below production costs, causing harm to domestic producers[2][7][3].

items.title: Japan unveils record $775B budget amid debt concerns

featured_image.name: Japan's fiscal 2026 budget to include record spending, sources say

items.description: Japan's parliament on Tuesday enacted an 18.3 trillion yen ($118 billion) supplementary budget for fiscal 2025, just as the government prepares to unveil its largest-ever initial budget exceeding 120 trillion yen ($775 billion) for fiscal 2026[1][2][3][4]. The twin spending packages underscore Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's aggressive fiscal approach, even as soaring government bond yields and mounting debt levels raise concerns about the nation's financial health.

items.title: Rupee plunges past 91 per dollar for first time

featured_image.name: India central bank's FX forward book swells for 2nd month ... - Reuters

items.description:
The Indian rupee plunged past 91 per dollar for the first time on Tuesday, marking the fourth consecutive session of record lows as foreign investor outflows and trade deal uncertainty intensified pressure on the currency[1][2][3][4][5].

At midday trading, the rupee touched 91.14 against the US dollar, down 36 paise from its previous close of 90.78[3][5][6][7]. The currency has depreciated approximately 1% over the past five trading sessions alone and fell from 90 to 91 in just 10 trading sessions[3][5][8][6].

items.title: States vow to defy Trump order on AI regulation

featured_image.name: DeSantis: Florida has ‘right’ to regulate AI rules despite Trump’s order

items.description:
Multiple states are vowing to continue regulating artificial intelligence despite President Donald Trump's executive order seeking to establish a single national standard, setting up a potential legal showdown between federal and state authorities over who controls oversight of the rapidly developing technology.

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis said Monday that his state has the right to regulate AI regardless of Trump's December 11 order, which threatens legal action and withholds federal funding from states with laws the administration deems "onerous and excessive." Speaking at Florida Atlantic University, DeSantis said the order "does not" prevent states from creating their own AI guidelines[1][2].

"Even reading it very broadly, I think the stuff we're doing is going to be very consistent," DeSantis said[3]. "But irrespective, clearly, we have a right to do this."

items.title: Asian, US stocks fall as markets await key jobs report

featured_image.name: Stocks slide as investors on edge ahead of data, central bank meetings

items.description: Asian markets tumbled Tuesday while US stocks slipped the previous day as investors braced for crucial employment data that could shape the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions in the year ahead, with concerns mounting over stretched valuations in the artificial intelligence sector.

items.title: Ford ends F-150 Lightning after $19.5B loss

featured_image.name: Ford To Stop Making All Electric F-150 Truck, In Shift To Hybrids

items.description:
Ford Motor announced Monday it is discontinuing production of the all-electric F-150 Lightning pickup truck and taking a $19.5 billion charge as the Detroit automaker pivots away from large battery-electric vehicles toward hybrids and more affordable EVs[1][2][3].

The company, which has lost $13 billion on electric vehicles since 2023, will replace the Lightning with an extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) featuring a gasoline generator that provides an estimated 700-mile range[1][2][4]. Production of the current Lightning ended this year after just three-and-a-half years on the market[5][6].

items.title: Tiny autonomous robots solve 40-year robotics challenge

featured_image.name: Penn and Michigan Create World's Smallest Programmable ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania and University of Michigan have unveiled the world's smallest fully programmable, autonomous robots, according to studies published December 15 in Science Robotics and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences[1][2][3]. The microscopic swimming machines, measuring 200 by 300 by 50 micrometers—smaller than a grain of salt—can independently sense temperature, process information, and operate for months while costing just a penny each[4][1][5].

The robots represent what researchers describe as a solution to a 40-year challenge in robotics. "We've made autonomous robots 10,000 times smaller," said Marc Miskin, assistant professor in electrical and systems engineering at Penn and senior author of both papers[1][5]. "That opens up an entirely new scale for programmable robots."

items.title: ISIS ideology drove Bondi Beach attack, Australian PM says

featured_image.name: AUSTRALIA-ATTACK-BONDI

items.description:
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese confirmed on Tuesday that the father-son duo behind the Bondi Beach massacre that killed 15 people were motivated by Islamic State ideology, as investigators revealed the suspects traveled to the Philippines last month and possessed homemade explosives alongside ISIS flags[1][2][3][4][5].

The declaration came nearly 48 hours after Sajid Akram, 50, and his son Naveed Akram, 24, opened fire on a Hanukkah celebration at Sydney's iconic beach on Sunday evening. "It would appear that this was motivated by Islamic State ideology," Albanese told national broadcaster ABC on Tuesday morning[1][6][7]. Federal Police Commissioner Krissy Barrett officially classified the attack as "a terrorist attack inspired by Islamic State"[4][8][9].
